title: Insider: For a day, IU plays like the team we thought it was
text:
Insider: For a day, IU plays like the team we thought it was Zach Osterman , zach.osterman@indystar.com Published 2:20   | Updated 30 minutes ago CLOSE x Share IU Insider Zach Osterman recaps the Hoosiers' 96-92 win over Ohio State to cap the regular season. Zach Osterman / IndyStar Hoosiers center Thomas Bryant (31) celebrates as the team opens up a large first half lead against the Ohio State Buckeyes at Value City Arena. Indiana won 96-92. (Photo: Joe Maiorana-USA TODAY Sports) 57 CONNECT 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
COLUMBUS, Ohio – Two sets of walls separated the visitors’ locker room at Value City Arena from the outer hallway leading to Saturday’s news conferences. But no amount of concrete could drown out the shrill whistle and rhythmic shouting that comprised IU's postgame rowdiness, as the Hoosiers celebrated an unexpected end to the regular season. 
“Everyone’s happy, because this is what we’re supposed to do,” junior guard James Blackmon Jr. said, “and getting wins in a tough conference is always good.” 
On the final afternoon of its regular season, Indiana (17-14, 7-11) finally played the way the Hoosiers have insisted for the last three months that they could, like Blackmon said they were “supposed to.” 
An 11-0 run to start and a record-setting performance buried the Buckeyes (17-14, 7-11) and sent IU into the Big Ten tournament with rare momentum. The Hoosiers’ points total, in a 96-92 win, was the most an opponent has ever scored in Value City Arena. 
Robert Johnson broke a weeks-long slump with a game-high 26 points, hitting 10-of-17 shots, while Blackmon had 22. 
“We saw that a little bit here a month ago with Michigan State. They came in here, hit their first six shots. But (Indiana) just kept going and going and going,” Ohio State coach Thad Matta said. “They were making shots at an alarming rate.” CLOSE x Share IU coach Tom Crean recaps the Hoosiers' 96-92 win at Ohio State, which set a record for most opponent points inside Value City Arena. Zach Osterman / IndyStar 
The win ensures IU will either begin next week’s Big Ten tournament in Washington, D.C., as the No. 10 or No. 11 seed, pending the outcome of Sunday’s Michigan-Nebraska game. 
And it got ugly early for an Ohio State team that would have ensured itself a first-round bye in the nation’s capital with a win. 
Indiana scored the game’s first 11 points as 3-pointers finally fell. This was the Indiana of a year ago — driving aggressively, snapping off passes and finishing from all over the floor. 
“They were on fire,” Ohio State forward Jae’Sean Tate said. “It seemed like every shot they were taking was going in.” 
• BOX SCORE : Indiana 96, Ohio State 92 
Ohio State never really steadied itself in that first half, IU’s lead at one point climbed as high as 18. But for Evansville native JaQuan Lyle’s 15 points, the 54-40 halftime Indiana lead might have been much worse. 
At halftime, Matta said he told his team to “make them feel us” defensively, predicting that the Buckeyes would have the lead down to just three points quickly. 
He was almost right. Ohio State rallied to within four in just four minutes, and even took a brief lead, as IU scored just 10 points in the first 11 minutes of the second half. For a moment, Indiana wavered, an all-too-familiar sight for a team that’s blown its share of opportunities this winter. CLOSE x Share IU junior guard Robert Johnson, who broke a long slump with 26 points in a 96-92 win Saturday, talks about his performance, and an IU win. Zach Osterman / IndyStar 
But Blackmon drained a 3-pointer. Johnson hit a jumper. Juwan Morgan built a 5-0 run all by himself. Steadily — methodically — Indiana turned that one-point deficit back into a 10-point lead, in a span of less than five minutes. 
“I’ve got tremendous confidence in them,” IU coach Tom Crean said. “I think it’s great for them though, to see that they can put the stops together.” 
Ohio State flirted with another comeback for the rest of the afternoon, even trimming IU’s lead to just two with four seconds left. 
This time, Indiana held firm. It did so, in part, because it managed to turn two so-persistent weaknesses into strengths. 
The Big Ten’s most turnover-prone team in league play, Indiana committed only 12 giveaways Saturday, in a high-possession game. Ohio State managed just 12 points off those turnovers. 
And while free-throw disparities have crippled the Hoosiers on the road this season — and Ohio State was one of the league’s best at earning free throws coming into play Saturday — IU finished Saturday even on attempts, and plus-two on points from the free-throw line. And that doesn’t even account for the multiple one-and-one front ends the Buckeyes missed, crippling their own comeback hopes. 
“We came out with the right mindset,” Johnson said. “That’s where it all started with us. Defensively, especially. We were really into guys and getting stops, and that translated really well offensively.” Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed.
